sprout.name: Sprout
sprout.roles: Full-stack Developer, Project Manager, Designer, and Product Owner
sprout.description:
Sprout is a social gardening application to promote bee-friendly and native-plant gardens across the Greater Vancouver area. Using the application, the Sprout team hoped to inspire users to connect with their community and learn more about the ecosystem around them.

As a Full-Stack Developer, some of my most notable contributions to the project includes the implementation of both the back and front-end of a user's sprout profiles (each individual plant's record), plant database search, plant database results, alerts, and leaderboard. Plant data collected was provided with courtesy from Kwantlen Polytechnic University's School of Horticulture (2015).

üèÜ Sprout is awarded Best Design in BCIT CST program's Projects II for the term of Fall/Winter 2021 out of 51 total projects.
sprout.retrospective: When my team and I started out, we were thinking of ways to bring technology into sustainable living. I‚Äôve been interested in the cause of protecting bees and Nicholas, our back-end developer, was getting into gardening and wanted to learn more about native plants in the Vancouver area. We combined these two ideas with an element of community because we all learned to emphasize how important community is after studying online throughout the pandemic.

successes.text: Completed a full PWA from scratch within 5-weeks.
Self-taught and applied new technologies such as React.js, Axios, Heroku, and Postgres/SQL under a condensed timeline after 3 months of coding.
Individually learned to connect front-end to back-end through studying back-end peers' code.
Quick problem solving and prioritizing minimum viable product goals
A glorious front-end that was awarded Best Design amongst 51 total projects.
Learning to create meaningful bonds within a team of strangers!
Thorough documentation for future improvements and implementations.

potentials.text: Implement a log-in process that will keep users logged in even after page refresh.
Expand on the social aspect of the application with better team engagement, forums, or chat options.
Inproving SQL statements to make use of aggregate functions, reducing the front-end processing load.
Creating team challenges to engage each community team.
CSS file clean-up, to create a consolidated, shared style sheet for page components with similar styling.
Polish bugs such as encryption for password and large image size upload.

capwise.name: CapWise
capwise.roles: Full-Stack Developer, Designer, and Project Manager
capwise.description:
CapWise introduces a crowd occupancy counter for retail spaces that will make use of counted data. Aside from counting crowd flow, CapWise offers special scheduling and marketing features to make use of in-store counting data.

In this project, I worked on the back and front-end of a count-tracking page, using local storage for log-in, and utilizing Firebase to make update, add, and delete calls to and from a NoSQL database. Aside from the front-end Counter page, I spent time to work on the Alerts, Settings, and User Authentication process.
capwise.retrospective:
Given a prompt to find pandemic solutions, my peers and I sought to consider the new normal of people counting in businesses. At the start of the pandemic, businesses were asked to crowd-control their stores. In an age of information and data, my team and I felt that there's a wasted use of this tracked data. Thus, CapWise seeks to use people tracking data to help assist small to medium business owners with their business decisions.

As a very-first full deployed project on the web, there were many interesting challenges and a lot of growth that came out of this project.

successes.text: Prioritized MVP and leveraged our skill-level to create a simple yet good-looking design.
Implemented update, add, and remove calls to Firestore, a NoSQL database.
Individually integrated a log-in/log-out and update settings process for users.
Designed a completely mobile-first design.
Successfully implemented my first alerts page.
Managed a team of three efficiently so that we were ahead of our deliverable timeline.

potentials.text: The organization of our NoSQL database can be improved, in specific, for our scheduling and marketing pages.
The application can be expanded to allow one user to have access to more than one store location.

namu.name: Namu
namu.roles: Game Developer, Pixel-Graphics Artist, Project Manager, and Content Researcher
namu.description:
Featuring in-house made pixel art and 8-bit tunes, this pixel-game takes players on a journey with the baby blue whale, Namu, who is searching for his home. During the journey, players will encounter environmentally-themed trivia that affects planet Earth's richest ecosystem: the Ocean.

As the game developers, we hope that players come out of this game learning more about the importance of Ocean conservation.

My role during this project was managing the tasks that needed to be complete, assisting in pixel-asset creation, and developing different aspects of the game logic including: the scrolling background, obstacle generation and variation, and trivia pop-up overlays.

üèÜ Namu won the Best Presentation Pitch Award from the Hack the Break 2021 hackathon.
namu.retrospective: The idea for Namu was prompted from a tweet about endangered whales having to contend with up to 1000 boats moving daily through feeding areas. I studied a course on Earth Ocean Ecosystems during my Bachelors and really took away from my course about the importance of Ocean conservation. The Ocean is a vast place and we often take for granted its existence, its importance on the environment we live in, and the variety of life inside it. Ultimately, we hoped that our project can encourage awareness of our environmental actions while pushing the boundaries of what we've learned over our first month and a half programming.

successes.text: Without prior knowledge, our team learned and implemented a game using PyGame in 24-hours.
There is heart and soul in this project! Building all the pixel art and music by ourselves is something we really pride ourselves on.
I learned how to visualize and animate assets using Asperite.

potentials.text: Our team developed using a Centralized workflow, which ran us into a few issues during development. In future projects that I would implement in a team, I would use Gitflow Workflow as best practice.
Under the time constraint, we were unable to get our object collisions working on the game, so it can be improved!
A possible consideration is to store trivia questions and answers in a database rather than a dictionary added in the code.

boriya.name: B√≥riya
boriya.description:
Begin your adventure as a being in the forest of B√≥riya. This text-based adventure is inspired by Dungeons & Dragons. Players will have to train by battling monsters until they are strong enough to defeat the void that has consumed the forest.

Written using Python 3, this game was designed with a generous amount of doc-testing, unit-testing, documentation, constants, and functions that are Pythonic and atomic.
boriya.retrospective:
This text-based game is very reminiscent of D&D. As a Rogue myself, it was really fun to work out the logic behind the game and really consider how to build atomic and Pythonic functions. A lot of the game planning started with the flowchart (you can see an image of it below and the actual PDF link above if you want to actually read it).

Another big part of this exercise was to really get comfortable with writing unit tests. All-in-all, I spent over 24 hours writing 158 unit tests involving many, many patches. It was a challenging time, but I truly learned a lot from the experience!

successes.text: Writing 158 unit tests independently using patches.
In my humble opinion, many beauitfully atomic functions were written in this program that I am proud of. üí£
Thorough planning through the use of a flowchart to plan all function logic.
Fun inclusion of ASCII art, colour-coding, and combat statistics. We could have made a simpler game, but we didn't.

potentials.text: We can easily expand on the perks of levelling up in this game and create a more expansive world.
My original plan was to also include a randomizer for objects that a player will encounter if they do not encounter an enemy. They would be able to engage with the object.
Towns, NPCs, and exchange of currency & goods can be added to the game for a more immersive experience.

ola-chat.name: Ol√† Chat
ola-chat.description:
The Ol√† Chat project is a front-end prototype of what an anonymous peer-support chat app might look like. The project was created with peer support in mind, providing people a space to speak with peers who have similar identities and experiences.

As a front-end developer, I assisted in the creation of the chat interface, landing page, and display-picture selection process.
ola-chat.retrospective:
This project was my first hackathon with a bunch of new coders who, including myself, have only been coding for 1 month. The project came from a place of shared advocacy for mental health and from my experience being a Crisis Line volunteer. For this project experience, I learned a lot about front-end UI/UX programming using the little tools and knowledge I've picked up and about consolidating CSS stylsheets for shared components across pages.

Our team had a lot of ideas for this project, but only so much time to complete it. A lot of these features that we would have loved to include are in the Project Potential tab below. In some ways, this was also the first time I had to consider prioritizing and limiting the scope of a project.

successes.text: First foray in coding full pages using HTML/CSS and Javascript.
By shadowing a project peer who is in UI/UX, I learned about how to create shared components across HTML pages.
Working under a time constraint for the very first time in a hackathon was challenging, but my take away from it was how to pare down a project scope to complete a project.

potentials.text: The first thing I would change, of course, is to actually implement a database behind the project, likely with a Relational Database.
We would like to add tags for listeners to identify themselves in different topic categories.
Implementation of forums and after-chat support links.
Providing a Crisis flag for Sharers to flag when someone may need more serious support.
Security measures to protect users, a way to report inapporpriate users of the application.
A log-in process for Listeners.
